246 Mo. High Street
PEOPLES BROADCASTING CORPORATION
Columbus 16, Ohio
November 2, 1953
Mr. Howard S. Frazier
Suite 723, Bond Building
Washington 5* C.
Dear Mr. Fraziert
I have your letter about Mr* George Bernstein.
Mr. Bernstein was employed as my assistant from March, 1952 to March,
1953. When we became dissatisfied with the operating results of our
Washington radio station, WOL, I assigned Mr. Bernstein to that station
as manager. He did a thorough job of analyzing the problem and made
drastic cuts in operating expenses through the re-organization of work
assignments. This left us with surplus personnel and Mr. Berstein
was able to help those people get jobs in other places and leave the
employ of our organization feeling that they hat been treated fairly.
Our business was largely concentrated in agilance accounts and
Mr. Bernstein, recognizing the changes taking place in Washington due
to fancied or real fear or unemployment by government workers,
concentrated his sales activity in diversifying our accounts. He
accomplished this task with some real success.
We sold WOL, subject to the approval of the Federal Communications
Commission, because Mr. Bernsteinfs analysis of the situation convinced
us that a 250 watt station in the Washington area was not a big enough
property to carry on the type of programming that we wish to offer.
Mr. Bernstein was very honest in his analysis, although he recognized
that his recommendations would create a dislocation problem for him.
Our radio organization is small, although we plan to enlarge. I do
not see a place where we can adequately use Mr. Bernstein’s abilities
in the near future. I feel it would be unfair to attempt to hold him
on a job which would not exercise his full capabilities® The personnel
people in our owner organisation, the Farm Bureau Insurance Companies,
feel there is a possibility of placing Mr. Bernstein in our Insurance
Companies, but I do not feel this would be a satisfactory type of
activity for a man who has been active in the broadcasting industry.
The work would be entirely different, and away from Mr. Bernstein’s
major interest.
I wold be glad to discuss Mr, Bernstein with those who might be
interested in employing him, and will be pleased to recommend him. He is
honest, intense, and a hard worker — a man with good ideas and a high
loyalty and understanding toward those to whom he reports and those whom
he supervises.
Sincerely yours,
/s/ Herbert E. Evans
Herbert E. Evans „ „
Vice President - General Mgr.
